speaker: Daniel Friedman
text: Hello everyone.

speaker: Daniel
text: Welcome to the Active inference Institute quarterly roundtable number two in 2023.

speaker: Daniel
text: It's June 30, 2023, and this is going to be our quarterly updates and ways that you can participate at the institute and in the active ecosystem.

speaker: Daniel
text: So welcome to the active inference institute.

speaker: Daniel
text: We're a participant battori online institute that is communicating, learning, and practicing applied active inference.

speaker: Daniel
text: You can find us at the links on this page and note that we'll be transitioning our emails over from activeinference@gmail.com towards Atactiveinference institute domains.

text: This is recorded in an archive Livestream, so please provide us with feedback so that we can improve our work.

speaker: Daniel
text: All backgrounds and perspectives are welcome, and we'll be following video etiquette for live streams today in the quarterly meeting number two of the year.

speaker: Daniel
text: We'll start at the institute scale, give some updates at the institute level, and then we'll look a little bit deeper into primarily education, but also research.

speaker: Daniel
text: And then I'll have some closing thoughts by way of a presidential address about where we're at with active inference.

text: And if you're watching live, please write comments and questions in the live chat and we will look to address those during.

text: We have about 20 currently active interns from all around the world, different backgrounds, levels of technical familiarity with the active inference, ranging from truly some of the people who I believe are experts, to people who just found out about active inference and wanted to use this program to accelerate their learning a lot.

text: Also in the last weeks and months I would like to commend the two individuals who know who they are who have completed their internship.

text: This has really been a great honor to work with you, both of you, and to those who are still active, I look forward to seeing those updates and continuing to work with you.

text: So interns tend to participate in one or more course or textbook group or maybe help out with some live streams.

text: So some of the projects that we'll look at later in this roundtable but then also most of the interns have a personal or background research agenda.

text: So live streams and journal are a great pair in the active block for instance project we continue to build the soft and hard skills associated with generative modeling in the active inference tradition.

text: And so we use the complex Adaptive systems modeling framework Cadcad to implement different active inference generative models.

text: This is a really great place.

text: We continue to refine and update the active inference ontology, which is the real language that we speak, whether it happens to be deployed in English or visually or in a programming language or however, the active inference ontology is how we're communicating and we develop that and offer it as a service to the niche.

text: In this project, we have multiple ongoing learning groups which we'll talk more about soon.

text: Yeah, we put it here, like for now at education adjective scale, but future it will be applied for all institute structure and activities.

text: We just take one of stable system of qualifications level from European and adopt it for how we can see it in application to active inference and participations in projects and so on.

text: And for now, we have a basic draft and we'll have discussions around with interested parties, different scales of institute, and finally have some stable form which will apply to different direction.

speaker: Daniel
text: Thanks.

speaker: Daniel
text: I'll just add a few notes on this first, just echoing your last point.

speaker: Daniel
text: If you're interested in active inference, professionalization education, qualification systems, even as a critic, we would really love to have you in the game.

speaker: Daniel
text: So please participate early, participate often.

speaker: Daniel
text: And I'll just highlight a few pieces of this system draft that are really exciting.

speaker: Daniel
text: First, it begins at level zero, which everybody de facto can have, perhaps even upon or before birth.

speaker: Daniel
text: Then, as the levels proceed, active inference is always being connected with domains and systems of interest.

speaker: Daniel
text: So it's about yes, and with active inference about connecting active inference to other fields and topics, understanding a different domain's ontology robotics or neuroscience or pure mathematics, whatever it may be.

speaker: Daniel
text: And working with active inference as you gain knowledge of the ontology and of the details of active inference.

speaker: Daniel
text: But it's not just a knowledge based qualification system.

speaker: Daniel
text: We also are looking to integrate skills and even project responsibility and autonomy.

speaker: Daniel
text: So just to give kind of an example of this, levels one and two, again, currently very tentative drafts, so for your engagement.

speaker: Daniel
text: But in levels one and two, people are able to act as basic learners and collaborators and begin to get a grasp on what terms we're using in active inference and how do those concepts relate to their field of interest.

speaker: Daniel
text: And we see this every single day in the textbook group.

speaker: Daniel
text: And in discussions, someone says, oh, I'm working as a physical therapist.

speaker: Daniel
text: And so in action, that's like the person moving their arm.

speaker: Daniel
text: That is where these levels are targeted.

speaker: Daniel
text: Level three begins to get into describing and understanding some of the technical details of what we do.

speaker: Daniel
text: Level four begins to approach the evaluation and recapitulation of technical models in active inference.

speaker: Daniel
text: Level five is related to comprehensive development and implementation, as well as in the projects and autonomy, exerting more supervision for self and others.

speaker: Daniel
text: Level six, developing advanced skills.

speaker: Daniel
text: Level seven, engaging with very specialized problem solving skills.

speaker: Daniel
text: And level eight, engaging in synthesis, evaluation and critical problem solving.

speaker: Daniel
text: So again, can't emphasize enough it's just a draft, and we are calling for your participation if this is something that you would be interested in using or engaging with.

speaker: Daniel
text: But we think this is going to be a really important direction for the active inference ecosystem carrying on to the textbook group.

speaker: Daniel
text: So in the active inference textbook group, we are working on and through the Par, Pazulo and Friston 2022 textbook.

speaker: Daniel
text: Currently we have cohort three working on the second half of the book and cohort four on the first half of the book.

text: Together, these two cohorts compromise about 150 people.

text: Here are, for example, questions that people have asked live or before or after a synchronous meeting where we can connect the specific figures and the ontology terms to people's uncertainties.

text: Here's the variational free energy equation 2.5, and the way that we can use the ontology to unpack and connect some of the dots with these equations.

speaker: Daniel
text: And in the last few weeks, we've actually taken that even further and explored how to use language models through Coda AI in this process.

speaker: Daniel
text: So here we have Equations 2.1 and Equations 2.2.

speaker: Daniel
text: They are being rendered in Coda via typing in LaTech.

speaker: Daniel
text: And then we are using language models within Coda to provide explanations, contextualizations for different backgrounds and expertises, and also translation into different languages, describing the variables and the notation and the who, what and why.

speaker: Daniel
text: So this has been a pretty fun avenue and a really cool example of how language models and education can be hand in hand and empower our own learning by using all kinds of models to help us, where frankly, it can be quite challenging, which is in understanding some of the analytical details of the framework.
